articles.headline: China’s Answer to Tesla Is Hopeful Entrant to Global Car Market
articles.snippet: Electric vehicles offer a new chance to Chinese car-making efforts that have floundered in the past. But lavish state aid could be as much bane as boon.
articles.abstract: Electric vehicles offer a new chance to Chinese car-making efforts that have floundered in the past. But lavish state aid could be as much bane as boon.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On a windswept lot near Beijing’s main airport, Lu Qun talks up the electric sports car he hopes will transform him into China’s Elon Musk.

articles.headline: Ahead of Theresa May’s Visit, Talk of Trade Deal Is Clouded by Politics
articles.snippet: President Trump’s plans for an agreement with Britain are more about political benefits than economic gains, which would almost certainly be modest.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s plans for an agreement with Britain are more about political benefits than economic gains, which would almost certainly be modest.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world according to President Trump, the United States and Britain are about to make their special relationship great again. Having cast off decades of global niceties — the United States by putting him in the White House, Britain by voting to leave the European Union — they can now forge a magnificent future.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Has Trump’s Ear, and Wall Street Takes Note
articles.snippet: The political tide might seem unfavorable for electric cars and solar panels, but the new president may see them as part of a job-producing future.
articles.abstract: The political tide might seem unfavorable for electric cars and solar panels, but the new president may see them as part of a job-producing future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The election of Donald Trump and the accompanying rehabilitation of fossil fuels should have been, by all rights, devastating for Tesla Motors.

articles.headline: Republicans Now Marching With Trump on Ideas They Had Opposed
articles.snippet: Republicans’ longstanding opposition to federal spending, along with other party orthodoxy, is being cast aside to support President Trump.
articles.abstract: Republicans’ longstanding opposition to federal spending, along with other party orthodoxy, is being cast aside to support President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — From the time Donald J. Trump became their candidate until he took the oath of office, congressional Republicans treated his policy pronouncements — largely out of step with Republican dogma — as essentially a distraction. He would talk. They would drive the policies.

articles.headline: Trump Strategist Stephen Bannon Says Media Should ‘Keep Its Mouth Shut’
articles.snippet: Mr. Bannon, one of President Trump's top advisers, gave a scathing assessment of the news media, calling it “the opposition party.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Bannon, one of President Trump's top advisers, gave a scathing assessment of the news media, calling it “the opposition party.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days after President Trump spoke of a “running war’’ with the media, his chief White House strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, ratcheted up the attacks, arguing that news organizations had been “humiliated” by the election outcome and repeatedly describing the media as “the opposition party” of the current administration.

articles.headline: Tax Plan Sows Confusion as Tensions With Mexico Soar
articles.snippet: President Trump’s plan for a wall on the border with Mexico erupted into a diplomatic standoff, as he appeared to embrace a proposal to tax all imported goods.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s plan for a wall on the border with Mexico erupted into a diplomatic standoff, as he appeared to embrace a proposal to tax all imported goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Trump’s decision to build a wall along the length of the United States’ southern border with Mexico erupted into a diplomatic standoff on Thursday, leading to the cancellation of a White House visit by Mexico’s president and sharply rising tensions over who would pay for the wall.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Binyamin Appelbaum and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Nearly 8 Decades Later, an Apology for a Lynching in Georgia
articles.snippet: The police chief in LaGrange, Ga., who is white, apologized for the death of a young black man by a white mob in 1940.
articles.abstract: The police chief in LaGrange, Ga., who is white, apologized for the death of a young black man by a white mob in 1940.
articles.lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Some people here had never heard about the lynching of Austin Callaway — about how, almost 77 years ago, he was dragged out of a jail cell by a band of masked white men, then shot and left for dead.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Alphabet’s Profits Stay Predictably Good in a Volatile Industry
articles.snippet: While other tech companies rise and fall with consumer tastes, Google’s parent has been consistent in generating huge earnings.
articles.abstract: While other tech companies rise and fall with consumer tastes, Google’s parent has been consistent in generating huge earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is almost boring how predictably good Alphabet’s earnings are these days — a trait not always shared by the company’s tech conglomerate peers.

articles.headline: Trump Will Call for a Pentagon Plan to Hit ISIS Harder, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The White House is drafting a presidential directive seeking an aggressive plan that could include American artillery and attack helicopters in action in Syria.
articles.abstract: The White House is drafting a presidential directive seeking an aggressive plan that could include American artillery and attack helicopters in action in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is drafting a presidential directive that calls on Defense Secretary James N. Mattis to devise plans to more aggressively strike the Islamic State, which could include American artillery on the ground in Syria and Army attack helicopters to support an assault on the group’s capital, Raqqa, officials said.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In a Corner, President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico Punches Back
articles.snippet: The cancellation of his trip to the United States ended months of diplomacy for a leader caught between his people and an unpredictable, and at times hostile, American president.
articles.abstract: The cancellation of his trip to the United States ended months of diplomacy for a leader caught between his people and an unpredictable, and at times hostile, American president.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hunkered down in the presidential palace, Enrique Peña Nieto, the unpopular leader of Mexico, was besieged on both sides.

articles.headline: Trump’s Economic Vows May Be Harder to Hit After a Slow 2016
articles.snippet: The economic expansion of only 1.6 percent in 2016 could bolster the case for infrastructure spending but complicate the president’s plans.
articles.abstract: The economic expansion of only 1.6 percent in 2016 could bolster the case for infrastructure spending but complicate the president’s plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s target for economic growth just got a little more distant.

articles.headline: Dubious Vote-Fraud Claim Gets the Trump Seal of Approval
articles.snippet: Presidential praise for a man whose claims on Twitter about illegal voting have been debunked time and time again.
articles.abstract: Presidential praise for a man whose claims on Twitter about illegal voting have been debunked time and time again.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To support his call for a sweeping federal inquiry into his claims of vast voting fraud, President Trump turned on Friday to a little-known conservative activist whose work on the issue has been widely discredited and who has trafficked in conspiracy theories.
